Even and Odd Functions

Constructing even and odd functions

A given function \(f(x)\) can always be split into two parts, one of which is even and one of which is odd. To do this write \(f(x)\) as \(\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)+f(x)]\) and then simply add and subtract \(\dfrac{1}{2}f(-x)\) to this to give \[\qquad f(x)=\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)+f(-x)]+\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)-f(-x)].\] The term \(\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)+f(-x)]\) is even because when \(x\) is replaced by \(-x\) we have \(\dfrac{1}{2}[f(-x)+f(x)]\) which is the same as the original. However, the term \(\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)-f(-x)]\) is odd since, on replacing \(x\) by \(-x\) we have \(\dfrac{1}{2}[f(-x)-f(x)]=-\dfrac{1}{2}[f(x)-f(-x)]\) which is the negative of the original.

Example

Separate \(x^3+2^x\) into odd and even parts.

Solution

\[\begin{align*}f(x) &= x^3+2^x,\\ f(-x)&=-x^3+2^{-x}. \end{align*}\]

Even part: \[\dfrac{1}{2} (f(x) + f(-x)) = \dfrac{1}{2}(x^3+2^x-x^3+2^{-x}) = \dfrac{1}{2}(2^x+2^{-x}).\]

Odd part: \[\dfrac{1}{2} (f(x) - f(-x)) = \dfrac{1}{2}(x^3+2^x+x^3-2^{-x}) = \dfrac{1}{2}(2x^3+2^x-2^{-x}).\]
